creator: bonevich@telocity.com
text:
It appears that in Tomcat 3.2.1 (as well as all other distributions I have
looked at, as well as 4) no distinction is made between the JSP and TAGDEPENDENT
<body-content> settings found in tag library descriptors when processing a JSP
file.  The org.apache.jasper.compiler.Parser class treats them identically and
processes the body of the tag as JSP.  TAGDEPENDENT is supposed to perform no
processing of the body at all, leaving it up to the tag implementation to decide
what to do with the body content.

I found the following patch for this code in the archives for tomcat-dev from
Dec 1999.  It appears to never have been introduced to the distribution or
to CVS or anything.  I have updated the Parser class in my own install and the
patch appears to work just fine.

*********************************************************************

To: <tomcat-dev@jakarta.apache.org> 
Subject: PATCH: tagdependent tags should not parse content 
From: "Danno Ferrin" <DFERRIN@novell.com> 
Date: Wed, 08 Dec 1999 18:19:24 -0700 

The bodycontent=tagdependent should provide a literal copy of the tag
content.  JSP will handle JSP elements first, but tagdependent
shoudlnt.

Index: src/share/org/apache/jasper/compiler/Parser.java

                              // Parse until the end of the tag body.

                              listener.handleTagEnd(bodyStart,
reader.mark(), prefix,

tli, ti);

!                             if
(bc.equalsIgnoreCase(TagInfo.BODY_CONTENT_TAG_DEPENDENT))

dependent,

content

!                             else
!                                 // it is JSP body content, so accept
all core elements
!                                 parser.parse(tagEnd);
                              reader.advance(tagEnd.length());

reader.mark(), prefix,

tli, ti);
